Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\\), where \\(x(t)\\) and \\(y(t)\\) are real functions governed by the differential equations \\(\\dot{x} = Ax + B\\) and \\(\\dot{y} = Cy + D\\), respectively. We investigate the behavior under the integral transform \\(T[z](t) = \\int_0^t e^{-s}z(s) ds\\).

If the transform \\(T[z](t)\\) is applied to \\(z(t)\\) at t = 0 and evolved to time t = T under the given differential equations, will the behavior of \\(z(T)\\) solely depend on \\(x(T)\\) and \\(y(T)\\) without consideration of the transform?
Explanation: The transform \\(T[z](t)\\) introduces a convolution with the exponential decay factor which modifies the trajectory and the effective influence of the initial conditions and the differential equations controlling \\(x\\) and \\(y\\). Therefore, \\(z(T)\\) will carry imprints of the integral transformation and not just the final states \\(x(T)\\) and \\(y(T)\\).
